title: Is The CRYPTO CRASH OVER!? Is The RALLY NEXT!?

chunks.text: What's up, guys? It's Dan from Coinbau Trading. Today, we're going to talk about why the current pullback is probably over and the catalyst that could cause the crypto market to bounce and rally in the coming days. If this is the kind of content that you enjoy, then be sure to smash that like button, subscribe to the channel, and ping that notification bell. Before we get started, do keep in mind that nothing in this video is financial advice. It's just my personal analysis of the crypto market. Your analysis could be different, and if it is, that's awesome because the more difference of opinion that we have, the better traders and the better investors we're all going to become. So to start off guys, I want to basically point out the fact that on Monday I had warned that we could see a pullback like we saw over the last 24 hours because we still needed to see Bitcoin fill the CME gap left from New Year's Day around 88,000 and Ethereum also had a CME gap from New Year's Day around 3,000. And that's basically what happened yesterday. So it was kind of within expectations, but of course that did freak out a lot of people and everyone's wondering is it over? Are we going to have another crash lower? Uh is the bare market finally here? Or many people would argue that it already is. But in my view, guys, this is something I've pointed out in previous videos. My kind of threshold for what counts as the crypto bare market is if we were to see uh either Bitcoin or the total crypto market cap fall below the Ballinger band moving average on the monthly. I know you hear lots of analysts like looking at, I don't know, like the 50week uh simple moving average or whatever on Bitcoin or these different levels that literally everyone is watching. I'm pretty sure I'm the only person who's watching the Ballingerband moving average on the monthly. And again, I'm surprised by that because it has historically served as a pretty clear line in the sand as to what counts as a bull market versus a bare market. As a rule of thumb, when either the total crypto market cap or Bitcoin is above the Ballinger band moving average on the monthly, then crypto is in a bull market. And when it's below the Ballinger band moving average on the monthly, that means crypto is in a bare market. There's a couple interesting things to note in this regard. And the first is that this entire cycle both for the total crypto market cap and for Bitcoin, we actually didn't see a proper retest of the Ballinger band moving average on the monthly uh until basically uh November of last year. So from a purely technical perspective, like just being objective here, the pullback that we saw basically in October, November, even into December, the technically speaking, that was completely normal and something that was long overdue ever since crypto prices started breaking out in October of 2023, which is kind of crazy to wrap your head around. Um, the other thing to kind of point out here is that we're seeing a nice three stars in the south pattern here, which basically suggests, and you can even kind of see it with your naked eye that the selling pressure, the selling momentum has kind of been slowing over the last couple of months, we can see that prices, in this case, the total crypto market cap is holding quite snugly around 3 trillion. And so long as we do not see a big break below this key support level on the total crypto market cap or Bitcoin, then in my view, the crypto market can recover and we could actually see the crypto bull market continue. But of course, in the short term, this is on the monthly, but in the shorter term, we do have to take things one step at a time, especially if we're actively trading the markets. That's a perfect segue into what's happened over the last couple of days, so not surprisingly at all, both the crypto market and the stock market and global markets seem to have stabilized after Japanese bonds also stabilized. This is something I had pointed out over the weekend and also pointed out on Monday. I don't think that the pullback that we've seen over the last couple of days has anything to do with Greenland.
